A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$, is defined as $\{a \in R ; \varphi(a)=0\}$, which is an ideal in $R$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring Epimorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Kernel of a Ring Homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the kernel of a ring homomorphism is defined independently of the concept of a ring epimorphism. The kernel of a ring homomorphism, 
$	ext{ker} \(\varphi\)$, is defined as the set of elements in the domain ring $R$ that map to the zero element of the codomain ring $R'$ under the homomorphism $\varphi$. This definition requires only the existence of a ring homomorphism and does not depend on the homomorphism being surjective, which is the defining property of a ring epimorphism.

Therefore, the definition of the kernel of a ring homomorphism does not require the concept of a ring epimorphism. The kernel can be defined and understood entirely within the context of a general ring homomorphism, regardless of whether it is surjective (an epimorphism) or not.
